text: insect pets are a major problem in vegetable production systems there are three ways of controlling insect pets as part of integrated Pest Management or IPM approach those are system based practices mechanical practices and insecticide trap crops are based on the principle of host preference that is insects have strong preference for food and actively seek the most appropriate host plants trap crops lure insects away from the main crop insecticide applications made to the Trap crop prent prents migration of pest into the main crop advantages of trap cropping include a low cost of Technology seed is the only cost compatibility with current forming practices increased biodiversity protection of natural enemies and reduction in Inc deide usage success of the Trap crop depends on the choice of trap crops and on designer layout if the pest source is unknown is recommended to use perimeter system with the Trap crops planted on all sides of the main crop this works well in small forms and rectangular Fields strip inter planting is more complex system and is suitable for large forms here is a photo of a perimeter trap crop demonstration aimed at reducing Lea footed bug damage in tomatoes in this case all four sides around the M crop replanted to nk300 variety of Ford sorghum the pest is attracted to the head or Pentacle of sorghum planted two weeks before the main crop here's a photo of strip intercop C in system where nk300 soron was planted in a wide swath across a large vegetable field remember to scout the Trap crop for Target Pest and use insecticides during Peak insect activity to reduce pest population if the pest is known trap crops can be used in a highly efficient manner using the sore sink approach in this layout trap crops are planted at specific locations to arrest insect migration it may take a few years of trap crop use on inform form to generate sufficient knowledge about the pest Source this is a graphical representation of how sorghum trap crops work for leaf footed bug control under high pest pressure the Trap crops served as source of food and Maiden sight two insecticide treatments on sorum were sufficient to reduce 78% of leaf footed bugs without treating the main crop here's a video of leaf footed bugs on sorghum trap crop in Southwest Alabama notice the high concentration of leaf footed bugs on every ear in the absence of trap crop the leaf of the bugs will feed on tomatoes and other crops resulting in very poor quality of produce producers can use trout crops creatively on their Farm in this case a producer in Alabama use sunflower and sorum trap crops all along the fence near the road making his field look attractive to cu's customers trap crops can also provide some weed control and wind reduction as side benefits there are many limitations of trap crop system that can be overcome with experience for additional information please refer to these trap crop Publications available online watch the other videos in the Trap crop series for advanced knowledge consult a regional Extension agent for designing a trap crop system for your form

vegetable production systems there are
three ways of controlling insect pets as
part of integrated Pest Management or
IPM approach those are system based
practices mechanical practices and

and actively seek the most appropriate
